content: This contribution hasn’t received enough positive votes from the community. The "FASTEST" option has therefore been deactivated.

Quite fun, but there's an ambiguity in the statement that scared me just now in a clash, haha. You say:

"categorize the trajectory based on the rounded vertical position (y_rounded) into near which is less than zero, or far which is more than zero", but don't specify what to do for 0.

Your code treats zero as far, so it would be good to reword it to "far which is zero or above".

Of course it won't come up practically, but it's good to have it clear. :)

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment:

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice little exercise to familiarise with long forgotten physics problems.

I like this problem.
Most of the relevant information is there to be used.

But I suggest to add a hint, how to convert degress in radians though, for users who don't know and need this information.

With this information it should be possible in <15min

❌ Rejected the contribution.
Comment: I think this would take longer than a few minutes to write.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I approve this solution because of its simplicity and practicality. It is relatively easy to solve, it is just very long which makes it difficult for people who are not so fast.
Ready for contributors to approve or reject this contribution!
Contribution rejected due to complaints regarding skill issues.

❌ Rejected the contribution.
Comment: This is a bit too long and clearly impossible in no statement mode.

❌ Rejected the contribution.
Comment: I reject this contribution because it is too complicated and I feel like it would take longer than a few minutes to write.

❌ Rejected the contribution.
Comment: I refuse this contribution because is too much about physics.
Ready for contributors to approve or reject this contribution!

Goal section
* The clash should focus on programming skills, not physics knowledge. Please provide the relevant formulas.

* Better to add some elements like loops and conditions. Currently it's just implementation of a formula.

Input section
* Please add line numbers and variable types to every description. For example,
<<Line 1>>: A float [[theta]]: The launch angle of the projectile in degrees.
(Other lines should be changed similarly.)

Output section
* The output is a string, not a tuple.

* Please specify the output format (the fixed phrase should be formatted as a {{constant}}).

Adapt this example to your clash:
{{Required answer is: ( [[a]] + [[b]] )}}
(Change the wording, the spacing and the variable names to fit your clash.)

* You must specify the rounding requirement. The default number of decimal places is not the same for every programming language.

Constraints section
* Please specify the ranges instead of a general description. This is important for some language users to determine what variable types to use.
Example: 0.0 ≤ [[t]] ≤ 10.0
(Other lines should be changed similarly.)

Thanks.

Modified based on your suggestions!

You're welcome.
Please always write a reason when you approve or reject a contribution. Thanks.
Thanks for your feedback!

Thank you for making some changes. Below are the outstanding matters:

Overall
* It's better to modify your clash so that some elements like loops and conditions are required in the code. Currently the clash is just about the implementation of a formula.

Output section
* Please delete "(x, y)".

* Please delete "at time t".

* Please add to the end:
{{Projectile position at time t = [[t]]: (x, y) = ([[x]], [[y]])}}. x and y should be rounded to _____ decimal places.

(Please fill in the blank, and amend your code and the cases accordingly.)

Constraints section
* Please specify the upper limits for v0, x0, y0 and g.

Thanks again.

Modified based on your suggestions.

You're welcome.

Thank you for your quick changes.

Output section
* Please change as follows:

<<Line 1>>: A string representing the position of the projectile at t:
{{Projectile position at time t = [[t]]: (x, y) = ([[x]], [[y]])}}
After calculating the trajectory, round [[x]] and [[y]] to the nearest integer.

<<Line 2>>: A string representing the category of the trajectory based on the rounded vertical position ([[y]]):
{{trajectory = far}} or {{trajectory = near}}

Goal section
* Please explain what trajectory is considered as {{far}} and what is considered as {{near}}.

Thanks again.

Modified based on your suggestions once more.

You're welcome.

We're almost there.

Goal section
* Please format "near",  "mediocre" and "far" as {{constants}} (they are not variables).

* No cases require an output of "mediocre". Please EITHER remove that description, OR add some cases for that and update Output section to include "mediocre".

Thanks.

Modified based on your suggestion. 

You're welcome!

I understand that you originally wrote that there's the case of "mediocre" trajectory too. Now that you've removed it, you've opened a gap of 0 to 5 which is not covered by any descriptions. Please fix that. Thanks.
Modified based on your suggestion.
I hope there isn't a case where rounded y is exactly 0! Otherwise, it's fine :)
